articles.headline: U.S. Sends Two B-52 Bombers Into Air Zone Claimed by China
articles.snippet: Officials said the United States military would continue to assert its right to fly through what it regards as international airspace after a recent Chinese claim to an “air defense identification zone.”
articles.abstract: Officials said the United States military would continue to assert its right to fly through what it regards as international airspace after a recent Chinese claim to an “air defense identification zone.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defying China, two long-range American bombers flew through contested airspace over the East China Sea, days after the Chinese announced they were claiming the right to police the sky above a vast area that includes islands at the center of a simmering dispute with Japan.

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, Partying Like It’s 1999 Once More
articles.snippet: A heady stew of technology, entrepreneurs and venture capitalists is simmering again, but along with the rich payouts and soaring valuations is an undercurrent of concern.
articles.abstract: A heady stew of technology, entrepreneurs and venture capitalists is simmering again, but along with the rich payouts and soaring valuations is an undercurrent of concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — These are fabulous times in Silicon Valley.

articles.headline: New Rules Would Rein In Nonprofits’ Political Role
articles.snippet: The Obama administration’s proposals would curtail political activity by tax-exempt nonprofit groups, a significant change for one of the fastest-growing sources of campaign spending.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration’s proposals would curtail political activity by tax-exempt nonprofit groups, a significant change for one of the fastest-growing sources of campaign spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Tuesday moved to curb political activity by tax-exempt nonprofit organizations, with potentially major ramifications for some of the biggest and most secretive spenders in American politics.

articles.headline: Online Help to Pick a Car and Make the Down Payment
articles.snippet: Automakers and dealers are turning to social networks to develop better ways to attract younger, first-time car buyers.
articles.abstract: Automakers and dealers are turning to social networks to develop better ways to attract younger, first-time car buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lindsay Frandsen thought about registering for gifts for her wedding, she realized that what she and her husband really needed was a car.

articles.headline: I.M.F. Shifts Its Approach to Bailouts
articles.snippet: The International Monetary Fund is advocating a more aggressive approach to debt restructuring that would shift some pain to the private sector, and away from German-style austerity.
articles.abstract: The International Monetary Fund is advocating a more aggressive approach to debt restructuring that would shift some pain to the private sector, and away from German-style austerity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund, convinced that Europe erred in forcing debtor countries like Greece and Portugal to bear nearly all the pain of recovery on their own, is pushing hard for a plan that would impose upfront losses on bondholders the next time a country in the euro area requests a bailout.

articles.headline: New Boom in Subprime Loans, for Smaller Businesses
articles.snippet: Wall Street has grown frustrated by low returns on other forms of debt and turned instead to riskier but more lucrative bets on ever-smaller companies.
articles.abstract: Wall Street has grown frustrated by low returns on other forms of debt and turned instead to riskier but more lucrative bets on ever-smaller companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small, little-known company from Missouri borrows hundreds of millions of dollars from two of the biggest names in Wall Street finance. The loans are rated subprime. What’s more, they carry few of the standard protections seen in ordinary debt, making them particularly risky bets.

articles.headline: Retailers Seek Partners in Social Networks
articles.snippet: Brick and mortar stores like Target and Walmart are engaging heavily with social networks, notably Pinterest, to clinch holiday sales.
articles.abstract: Brick and mortar stores like Target and Walmart are engaging heavily with social networks, notably Pinterest, to clinch holiday sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — “Showrooming” is no longer a bad word.

articles.headline: A Plea to Avoid Crush of Users at Health Site
articles.snippet: White House officials, fearful that the federal health care website may again be overwhelmed this weekend, have urged their allies to hold back enrollment efforts so the insurance marketplace does not collapse under a crush of new users.
articles.abstract: White House officials, fearful that the federal health care website may again be overwhelmed this weekend, have urged their allies to hold back enrollment efforts so the insurance marketplace does not collapse under a crush of new users.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials, fearful that the federal health care website may again be overwhelmed this weekend, have urged their allies to hold back enrollment efforts so the insurance marketplace does not collapse under a crush of new users.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Karzai’s Bet: U.S. Is Bluffing in Warning on Security Pact
articles.snippet: Even many of President Hamid Karzai’s friends have criticized his refusal to conclude a security agreement between Afghanistan and the United States.
articles.abstract: Even many of President Hamid Karzai’s friends have criticized his refusal to conclude a security agreement between Afghanistan and the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When President Hamid Karzai met with an audience of supporters gathered by the Afghan state television network, RTA, six months ago, he was asked what he would consider a favorable conclusion to the security negotiations he was conducting with the United States.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Alissa J. Rubin
